channel.title: technology on Barefoot Rob
channel.description: Recent content in technology on Barefoot Rob

item.title: time to post an xkcd comic
item.description:
##08:00 Saturday 30 March 2013 7:47am Saturday 30 March 2013 This image at https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/time.png been changing since it was posted on 25 March 2013.
Thanks to @Aubron Wood for this replay of the xkcd Time scene so far. Explanation of xkcd Time at explainxkcd

item.title: my floating virtual lego blocks
item.description: ##18:52 Sunday 24 March 2013 6:44pm Sunday 24 March 2013 After reading on HN that Google has discontinued Blocked Sites, I was browsing through the extensions available for Chrome, and found Build With Chrome. My creation hasn’t been approved yet, but it’s apparently visible if you click Rob’s floating v-shaped Lego thing. It looks something like this

item.title: 瞑想頑張れ, my soon to be new meditation timer
item.description: ##23:11 Monday 11 March 2013 This weekend I mostly put together what I’m calling the 瞑想頑張れ meditation timer, which is a bit like referring to “ATM machines” but hey at least it’s two different languages. It’s now available on github: 瞑想頑張れ at https://github.com/thunderrabbit/meiso-gambare. There are several meditation timers on the app store, but I hadn’t found one with the unique feature I wanted. Sometimes when I meditate, I really get into it and don’t want to stop when the original time is up.

item.title: ios provisioning portal down for 8 hours (at least) can't create provisioning profiles
item.description:
##07:42 Friday 15 February 2013 I wonder wtf happened. We are performing maintenance on the provisioning service. All provisioning requests will remain in pending status until maintenance is complete, at which time all pending requests will be automatically processed. I took this screenshot last night at 11:22pm. It’s now 7:34am as I write this, so it’s been down for more than 8 hours.
People on ASE are wondering as well, but not as many people are wondering as who are saying it’s not a good question.

item.title: killer snowman on DrawQuest
item.description: ##12:57 Sunday 10 February 2013 I just thought of a new idea for DrawQuest. I can’t show the full animation here, but if you have an iPad, download the app, and find me (thunderrabbit), you can see it. I drew a snowman who then thought about killing his maker, but then the dog barked and the snowman reverted to his normal happy state. This works easily because the eraser too erases down to the original image, not down to the blank canvas.

item.title: installed an aquarium above the kitchen sink
item.description: ##22:17 Friday 08 February 2013 Thanks to the incredible Sim Aquarium 3D we have an aquarium above our kitchen sink! What an amazing world. I can see several points where the app could be improved with future technology, but I’ve honestly never seen any computer technology so closely approach the look of a live aquarium. My suggested future development, possibly in order of easiest to hardest: larger background so rotating the device doesn’t force zoom-in

item.title: haha chatbot wants to get on webcam in a few sex
item.description: ##13:26 Friday 08 February 2013 xxxbabygirl.rachelxo51: heya :) me: hi me: have we met? xxxbabygirl.rachelxo51: hi thanks for accepting my invite =3D) 21/f here…..ya busy? me: not busy right now me: how about you? xxxbabygirl.rachelxo51: there’s never anyone on here 2 talk 2 anymore so i just took a shot and send you an invite lulz xxxbabygirl.rachelxo51: well whatcha up to? me: I’m at work me: where are you? xxxbabygirl.rachelxo51: ah cool.

item.title: Xcode, what are you doing?
item.description: ##20:46 Friday 01 February 2013 I’m trying to get some work done; I’m trying to give my time and money to Apple so I have a chance to make a nickel. Why is the provisioning process so obtuse? Am I just an idiot who can’t figure it out? Why does Xcode have so many bugs? Did I write it? As I write this, Xcode is locked up. Apparently I’m going to have to force close it.

item.title: excellent progress in new card game
item.description: ##12:46 Saturday 26 January 2013 Tariq and I are creating a game of memory for iOS. This is my first project that uses blocks, and I must agree, they make coding a lot lot easier!! This is my second big iOS project, a lot of which is based on Matthijs Hollemans’ game Snap (currently without the multiplayer stuff), one of Ray Wenderlich’s excellent tutorials. I’ve just gotten the in-game tutorial to work, though its alignment… isn’t.

item.title: sweet video of all known exoplanets
iOS meetup featuring Tonny, Yi, and Tracey
item.description: ##13:49 Saturday 15 December 2012 Today at the iOS meeting, Tonny gave a presentation on LLDB, Yi gave a presentation on iOS 6 Constraints, and Tracey gave a case study of customer service prowess. I’m looking forward to Matt’s iOS classes starting in January. He said he wants to start with “what’s really going on under the surface of Xcode,” an idea I heartily agree will help me figure out wtf is going on half the time with Xcode.

item.title: self balancing electric motorcarcycle
item.description: ##21:03 Wednesday 12 December 2012 WANT

item.title: why thank you
item.description:
##21:01 Wednesday 12 December 2012
It’s nice to just click update and have it update. (I didn’t even back up my data. shhhh)

item.title: dream if iHad iPad
item.description: ##07:42 Tuesday 11 December 2012 Riding in the back of a car, holding Lin’s iPad, I thought, “man if I had an iPad, I could easily write in my journal all the time.”

item.title: silly OS X
item.description:
##19:43 Friday 07 December 2012
I emptied my computer’s trash and at the same time wiped my external drive.

item.title: This URL will not exist in 2022
item.description:
##21:20 Saturday 24 November 2012 Not this URL, but this one: https://www.longbets.org/601/, or so the bettor suggests. I’m sure the URL will work fine, along with its friend https://longbets.org/601/ as well as future URIs in to-be-developed retrieval systems. Anyway, I just thought the bet was interesting, so I took a couple screenshots.
I wonder if the URL for this blog entry will still work; I’ve been debating ditching Wordpress for another home built system, perhaps using an upgraded version of my old system.

item.title: gravity lamp
item.description: ##17:57 Thursday 21 February 2008 Clay Moulton - Core77’s Greener Gadgets Design Competition 2008 Gravia is an LED-lit floorlamp energized by people. To light Gravia, the user places a mass approximately 48” above the ground, that, in falling, powers a mechanism, generating electricity. Gravia harnesses the potential energy imparted by the user, rather than relying on any existing electrical infrastructure. This is a must have item. Too bad it doesn’t seem to be for sale yet!

item.title: Discovery News : Spy Satellite Could Crash to Earth
item.description: ##12:47 Wednesday 30 January 2008 It was not clear how long ago the satellite lost power, or under what circumstances. Discovery News : Spy Satellite Could Crash to Earth It’s a spy satellite!! How can they not know when it lost power? It seems more likely that someone knows quite well exactly when it lost power, but just didn’t say anything publicly. BUT…. maybe there are just so many spy satellites all on autopilot that someone didn’t notice?

item.title: Plans for World's First Commercial Spaceport
item.description: ##12:37 Wednesday 10 October 2007 New Mexico Spaceport Authority unveiled the design for the world’s first public launching and landing site for space vehicles, Spaceport America Virgin Galactic Preps for Liftoff at World’s First Commercial Spaceport Tight. I’ve always enjoyed reading articles about astronomy and wanted to be an astro-physicist (actually just wanted my name in Discover Magazine)… I’m glad that soon we’ll be able to fly so high…

item.title: Geologists recover rocks yielding unprecedented insights into San Andreas Fault
item.description: ##18:52 Friday 05 October 2007 Sensitive seismometers and tiltmeters to be installed in the SAFOD borehole directly above the spot that ruptures will observe for the first time the birthing process of an earthquake from the zone where the earthquake energy accumulates. Preliminary observations made in 2006 already have revealed the tiniest earthquakes ever observed—so small they have negative magnitudes. Geologists recover rocks yielding unprecedented insights into San Andreas Fault

item.title: The Hindu News Update Service
item.description: ##02:04 Wednesday 26 September 2007 We should explore the possibility of generating electric power through single cycle fusion process using Helium-3 on the moon,” Kalam said.The former president, who led India’s successful missile programme, said energy production through fossil fuel generates 30 billion tonnes of CO2 annually and countries should look for cleaner energy. The Hindu News Update Service https://ma.gnolia.com/badoscici I quoted above the part with which I agree most.

item.title: 3G in Japan vs stagnation in the US
item.description: ##13:58 Wednesday 03 January 2007 Regarding WiFi in Japan vs the US, Jesse wrote: We already have 4G in Japan…. and it is already too slow but boasts speeds of 100mbps. 3g is only good for non-mobile systems. It only goes a max of 384kbps for mobile systems, and that is if it has a good connection… Dude explained: beacause the US is so concerned with “preserving the free market”, our government refuses to mandate a standard.

item.title: flexible transisters
item.description: ##21:21 Monday 24 July 2006 The techniques could allow flexible semiconductors to be embedded in fabric to create wearable electronics or computer monitors that roll up like a window shade. Research dishes out flexible computer chips (Jul 18, 2006) This should be pretty amazing. As they say, a paradigm shift. I can just imagine it will start with monitors wrapped around poles in shopping malls, and in expensive pubs and clubs.

item.title: writely
item.description: ##18:44 Tuesday 11 July 2006 writely.com Writely, the online word/blog processor, allows one to read/write/upload/save/collaborate text documents online, including, apparently, posting to one’s blog, which I am testing now.Props to writely crew for doing such a good job that Google has recently scooped them up in its plan to replace local storage with infinite storage online.Registration to writely is closed, except via invitation. Special props to Piet for inviting me!

item.title: hilarious "solution" to permafrost melt
item.description: ##09:51 Sunday 18 June 2006 the engineers devise an insulation system – a thick layer of crushed rock over the permafrost. LiveScience.com - Surprising Side Effects of Global Warming How incredibly ridiculous to imagine this is any kind of good solution.Â It may keep the ground frozen for a bit, but certainly not for a particularly long time, and it definitely doesn’t solve the second-basic issue (*) the ground is shifting!

item.title: Google Click-to-Call
item.description: ##13:41 Thursday 24 November 2005 Google foots the bill for all calls - local and long-distance. Google Click-to-Call Holy shinoli!!! How can this be abused? How can they afford it? Woah.

item.title: offshore wind power
Free Wi-Fi
item.description: ##03:19 Friday 28 October 2005 Google proposed to build an IEEE 802.11b/g Wi-Fi mesh network that delivers more than 1 megabit per second of capacity throughout the city. PCWorld.com - Google Describes its Wi-Fi Pitch This would be pretty fresh… A city where we could just walk around and be connected… This would drive a market for cameras that upload to a blog and realtime wearable video cameras… Wow.

item.title: To the moon!
item.description: ##06:45 Tuesday 25 October 2005 How We’ll Get Back to the Moon NASA - How We’ll Get Back to the Moon This looks pretty cool. I’m intrigued by the cargo and crew launching separately, but I guess it makes sense to keep the crew away from the heavier launch thing. It will be interesting to see how they will handle disruptions in launching the second vehicle. If the first one is in orbit and then the second can’t be launched, how long can the first one stay in orbit to wait?

item.title: Google Earth
item.description: ##01:05 Friday 21 October 2005 Wow. Google Earth rules. I am 99% certain I have found Scott, my favorite car parked at my office at FSD about 3 or 4 years ago in Houston. That is awesome. I sent a ‘bookmark’ to myself (and Dude and Fred); I wonder if I can post it in here somehow.

item.title: Plasma pencil kills germs
item.description: ##00:50 Monday 17 October 2005 Plasma pencil kills germs This seems pretty cool. In a way, it’s like the first example of something cool that I’d never even considered possible; I thought plasma was necessarily gajillions of degrees. But now it’s available in a handheld little thing… And sounds like it could become commonplace. “Yeah, my pocketknife has a corkscrew, screw driver, plasma beam, and a knife!”

item.title: automatic image categorisation
item.description: ##03:39 Tuesday 04 October 2005 automatic image categorisation This seems pretty sweet. Google could use this technology to further optimize its image search. I could use this technology to get the pictures on my website arranged! Amazing to imagine that we are now living in a time that computers don’t recognize what’s in photographs. Seriously.

item.title: Magnetic Microchips
item.description: ##01:39 Saturday 01 October 2005 Magnetic Microchips Replaces Electronic Semiconductor Wow. I don’t presume to know how electronic chips work, nor how magnetic chips work, but I do understand things like “smaller” and “do not generate heat” This is super important to me as my computer gets scorching hot after just several minutes of being on unless I use an external fan.

item.title: 600 barrels of loot found on Crusoe island
item.description: ##14:04 Thursday 29 September 2005 Guardian | 600 barrels of loot found on Crusoe island Obviously the money belongs to Arturito. Finders, keepers. Too bad he’s not sentient, yet. What would a sentient robot do with $10B? It sounds like too much money for it to be good news, ya know? Papal rings??? Incan statues?? I seriously think it should be excavated by ARCHAEOLOGISTS, and super tight security around the whole thing.

item.title: Dudeâs Drivel Â» Deep Impact vs. Missile Defense
item.description: ##03:47 Tuesday 27 September 2005 Dudeâs Drivel Â» Deep Impact vs. Missile Defense This is cool, but I’m actually testing trackback stuff. I don’t understand it quite yet.

item.title: 1000 feet closer to space
item.description: ##03:36 Tuesday 27 September 2005 LiftPort Staff Blog Â» Blog Archive Â» Photos & More from 1,000-ft Robot Test Also: https://www.space.com/businesstechnology/050923_spaceelevator_test.html I love the idea of a space elevator. Or fifty around the globe. How big of a ribbon will they have to be????

item.title: nanotechnology detects cancer proteins in single drop of blood
item.description: ##03:20 Tuesday 27 September 2005 medicalnewstoday.com/medicalnews.php?newsid=31091 This seems to herald a day where the family physician (or anyone) can do a quick test to see if we have cancer. Totally kick ass.
